programme.title: Dive in Tokyo
programme.sub-title: Nakano - From Dog Sanctuary to Anime Wonderland
programme.desc: Home to manga, anime and toy stores, the Nakano neighborhood is famous for its subculture spirit. As we explore, we discover its rich past as a dog sanctuary, blossom-viewing spot and military hub.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: KABUKI KOOL

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Fashioning One-of-a-Kind Costumes: Ito Satomi / Costume Designer
programme.desc: Ito Satomi has designed costumes for many top-tier figure skaters from Japan and overseas. She shares her passion and inspiration for her craft.

programme.title: Japan's Top Inventions
programme.desc: Discover the stories behind renowned Japanese products alongside our reporter. This time: Water Jet Cutters.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Crafting the Ultimate Kitchen Knife: Kurosaki Yu / Blacksmith
programme.desc: Kurosaki Yu is a blacksmith specializing in Echizen cutlery, a 700-year-old Japanese craft. His knives are sought after by chefs in Japan and overseas. He talks about achieving ultimate sharpness.

programme.title: JAPAN DELISH
programme.desc: Crisp, hot and delicious Japanese gyoza! How did gyoza come to be so beloved in Japan? Taste the delicious truth for yourself!

programme.title: National Parks of Japan
programme.desc: Akan-Mashu National Park is located in Japan's northernmost prefecture of Hokkaido. It's home to Lake Akan, Lake Kussharo and Lake Mashu, 3 unique lakes formed by repeated volcanic activity. Join us as we take in its stunning winter sights and learn about the indigenous Ainu culture, which was influenced by the surrounding nature.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: We break down a print that warps space to allow the viewer to be in 2 places at once: Shinobazu Pond, known for its lotus flowers, and the Sumida River, one of Edo's busiest waterways.

programme.title: Science View
programme.sub-title: The Dream of Generative AI Engineering - Koji Nishiguchi, Nagoya University
programme.desc: Research is ongoing to apply 3D generative AI to structural design. Koji Nishiguchi of Nagoya University is on the frontline, with a simulation method which used to be thought of as impractical.

programme.title: FRONTRUNNERS
programme.desc: Mongolia's culture of meat-eating is contributing to health problems in this developing economy. Chef Suzuki Yuko aims to introduce more vegetables through workshops and improved hospital menus.

programme.title: National Parks of Japan
programme.desc: Towada-Hachimantai National Park was shaped through volcanic activity. It comprises a mystical lake, a nature-filled gorge and numerous marshes. programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Akita's Festivals Light Up Long Winters
programme.desc: The city of Senboku in Akita Prefecture is made up of three towns: Tazawako, which has the deepest lake in Japan; Nishiki, home to farming scenery: and Kakunodate, called the little Kyoto of Tohoku. In addition to the stunning nature and samurai culture, visitors can enjoy spectacles related to the Lunar New Year. Catrina Sugita experiences the area's winter lifestyle and its fiery festivals.

programme.title: Dining with the Chef Mini
programme.desc: Dining with the Chef Mini introduces traditional techniques and resourceful recipes in just 5 minutes! Chefs Saito and Rika present their unique approaches to cooking delicious Japanese food. In this episode, chef Rika will show you a plating technique for noodles using soba, buckwheat noodles topped with meat. Join us and learn how to make an original meaty buckwheat noodle dish at home!

programme.title: JAPAN DELISH
programme.desc: "Curry rice," one of Japan's most iconic national dishes. How did Jimbocho, Tokyo become a curry town?

programme.title: National Parks of Japan
programme.desc: Daisen-Oki National Park comprises islands and a mainland area with a coast and mountain range. Home to shrines and sacred mountains, it's been the setting of Japanese myths. Join us on a cruise with spectacular sights and a trek across the mainland, where we observe a daily morning ritual at Miho Shrine and climb the majestic Mt. Daisen.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: A dapper young man sits in a teahouse with his older companion when a young woman catches his eye. From the way they're looking at each other, it's clear that there's something going on between them.

programme.title: Japan in Focus
programme.desc: To place a greater focus on their careers, women in Japan are increasingly using egg freezing to save pregnancy for later in their lives, accepting the cost and physical strain that treatment entails.

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: An Everyday Family Diner in Tokyo
programme.desc: At a family diner, we meet customers of all ages, from solo diners to families and big groups. These diners' stories may seem ordinary, but all kinds of quiet dramas lie within these everyday moments.

programme.desc: In 1985, a passenger jet crashed into Osutaka Ridge, killing 520 people. Kurosawa Kanichi looks after the area, preserving memorials and guiding bereaved family members up the mountain.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.desc: Hello there! It's me, Tama. Don't mind me, I just saw a hole and wanted to cool my paws in it. Looks like Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko are preparing their annual dried persimmons. So tasty! So sweet! But it takes weeks before they're ready! I don't know if I can wait that long!

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. In this episode, poet and literary translator Peter MacMillan travels to Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture, where the writer and journalist Lafcadio Hearn (1850-1904) lived. Hearn is known for Kwaidan, a collection of ghost stories, and other works that explore the essence of Japan. He also loved insects and resonated deeply with Japanese insect culture. From the Lafcadio Hearn Memorial Museum in Matsue, we introduce some expressions related to insects, or mushi.

programme.title: Easy Japanese
programme.sub-title: #5 I studied by listening to the radio.
programme.desc: Explain how you learned Japanese by putting "de" after the method you used. For example, "rajio de", meaning "by listening to the radio".

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.sub-title: Sing for Ukraine, Sing for Peace
programme.desc: Ukrainian musician Kateryna gives concerts all around Japan playing the bandura. Russia's invasion prompted her to support displaced people in Japan, hoping her music will bring peace to her homeland.

programme.title: HELLO! NHK WORLD-JAPAN
programme.desc: In November 2025, the Deaflympics—an international sports competition for the hearing impaired—was held in Japan for the first time. NHK WORLD-JAPAN showed related programs, and promoted its services.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Giving Your All for a Moment's Action: Obikane Nobuyuki / Stunt Performer
programme.desc: World-class stuntman Obikane Nobuyuki won an Emmy Award for his work on the hit historical TV drama series "Shogun." He talks about his techniques for achieving realistic, thrilling action.

programme.title: Nun's Seasonal Calendar
programme.desc: Join us as we learn about life at the Otowasan Kannonji Temple through 24 terms from the solar calendar. First, we follow the nuns on the day of Taisetsu as they prepare yuzu pepper and yuzu miso, seasonal specialties enjoyed at the end of the year. And then on the day of Toji, they use pumpkin, considered a lucky food, to make three mouthwatering treats: soup, noodles and flan.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: Summer is winding down, and tonight down by Edo Bay the streets are filled with professional entertainers, food sellers and revelers. It's getting late, but this party is just getting started.

programme.title: Ethical Every Day
programme.desc: This time, we focus on ethical circular fashion, from a recycled wool brand featured at Paris Fashion Week to polyester products given new life thanks to recycling on the molecular level.

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: Tsukemono is a simple food made by pickling vegetables and other ingredients in seasonings such as salt and vinegar. It started as a preserved food, and some are made by fermentation. It is never the main dish, but is an essential part of the Japanese diet. Every region has its own special tsukemono. Tsukemono can be enjoyed not only for its taste, but also for its flavor, color and the sound it makes when chewed. We take a journey of tsukemono around Japan.

programme.title: Medical Frontiers
programme.sub-title: Straightening a Bent Spine Through Exercise
programme.desc: Adult spinal deformity (ASD) can develop due to age-related muscle loss or osteoporosis. We introduce ways to improve ASD through exercise therapy and explore AI-based efforts for early detection.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.sub-title: #34 Ensuring a Safe Journey in Japan
programme.desc: The number of foreign visitors to Japan has been on the rise since the COVID travel restrictions have been lifted. However, many are not fully aware of natural disasters that strike Japan such as earthquakes, tsunamis, and typhoons. Now, there are efforts to ensure the safety of visitors during disasters. The newly developed "announcer drone" translates text into 29 languages and instructs people to evacuate while flying. At evacuation centers, local governments are well prepared to notify important information to those who do not understand Japanese, using translation systems developed for emergency situations.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Using Sound to Prevent Animal Accidents: Tsuji Masachika / Specially Assigned Professor, Okayama University of Science
programme.desc: Tsuji Masachika is working on using sounds that birds dislike to keep them away from airplanes and prevent bird strikes. He talks about seeking ways for wild animals and humans to coexist in harmony.

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.desc: Food waste is a major driver of global warming. One institute warns that greenhouse gas emissions from food waste exceed those of nations like India and Russia. We examine the data behind this issue.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: A Napping Boy Dreams of Monsters
programme.desc: When a little boy's nap is disturbed by a bad dream, his mother comes to his rescue. What was terrorizing him? We examine a print that shows how much the Edo townspeople cherished their kids.

programme.title: Medical Frontiers
programme.sub-title: Straightening a Bent Spine Through Exercise
programme.desc: Adult spinal deformity (ASD) can develop due to age-related muscle loss or osteoporosis. We introduce ways to improve ASD through exercise therapy and explore AI-based efforts for early detection.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Camping is increasingly popular in Japan, with around eight million people participating annually—in various different ways. Popular styles include women-only trips and solo camping. Some people prefer glamping, where they don't have to set up their own tent. Camping has also been drawing attention as a good way to develop useful survival skills. We investigate why so many people in Japan are going camping these days, and look at some new equipment options.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.desc: Yoshimune, the shogun who saved the city of Edo. Through disaster and economic strife, alongside its people, his wisdom shaped the future of the place now called Tokyo.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: This episode focuses on kawa, which means both river and stream. These flowing bodies of water have played a central role in Japanese life and philosophy, as reflected in the Japanese language.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: In Kurume, Fukuoka Prefecture, the first week of the new year culminates in Oniyo: the night of the oni, or demon. Six giant torches, measuring 13 meters and weighing 1.2 tons, are moved around a shrine precinct. They create a shadow in which the oni can emerge. One torch is taken to the river, where the oni conducts a ritual that cleanses people of their troubles. This matsuri also recounts a 1,600-year-old story about a local hero defeating an outlaw—who goes on to become the oni.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: JAPAN DELISH
programme.desc: Ever heard of an-pan?! From fruit sandwiches to curry-filled delights, Japanese bread is full of delicious surprises!

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: In February 2022, an American space exploration company simultaneously launched 49 satellites. Yet not long after, 40 of those satellites fell out of orbit and burned up upon re-entry into the Earth's atmosphere. Similar accidents have occurred frequently in the past. The cause of such incidents is believed to be solar flares, huge explosions that occur on the sun's surface. Solar flares can also lead to other disasters that threaten our daily lives, such as major power outages, radio interference, and communication problems for airplanes and ships. Why do solar flares occur? We'll visit some researchers in Japan that are working hard to understand their mechanism and predict future occurrences.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Kagoshima Prefecture / Morinaga Kunihiko (Fashion designer) Priestesses on Amami Oshima wore patchwork robes with triangular butterfly designs, intended to protect the wearer from unseen spirits.
